abstracts.cdata!:
The pay-as-you-go pension system
            Kazakhstan inherited from the Soviet Union had an
            inefficient collection and payment system. After the country
            gained independence from the Soviet Union, economic
            dislocation together with rising budget deficits and
            mounting pension arrears led to growing social tension among
            the people. The boiling point came in 1997. Pensioners had
            not received any money for almost a year, arrears exceeded
            36 billion tenge, and the government had no means to pay
            them. Its efforts to provide essential goods and food
            instead of the pension didnt help. Despairing pensioners
            organized mass protests across the country.

repnme.cdata!:
Kazakhstan - Pension Reform Structural
            Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated as satisfactory
            and sustainability is considered, likely. Overall
            performances by the Bank and the Borrower are judged as
            satisfactory. These were the lessons learned from this
            experience: Establishment of a private pension system can
            provide a major stimulus to capital markets development. In
            parallel with efforts to strengthen regulation of capital
            markets, pension reform significantly increased the funds
            available to flow into productive investment
            opportunities--including the debt instruments of private
            firms and municipal and regional governments. Limited
            privatization has constrained equity investment
            opportunities. Further privatization of viable firms, as
            well as improved corporate governance and accounting
            transparency, would offer substantial benefits for the
            country. In a radical pension reform, sufficient time should
            be provided for developing administrative capacity. The Bank
            became involved in pension reform after Kazakhstan had
            decided on the design of the reform. Even though it was not
            an ideal situation, and more time and more detailed analysis
            might have been preferable, the Bank made the correct
            decision to "board the train." To the greatest
            extent possible, conditionality should focus on outcome.
            Lastly, to the extent possible, conditionality focused on
            unpredictable exogenous circumstances should be avoided.

5085950.majtheme: Economic management,Social protection and risk management

repnme.cdata!: Kazakhstan - Pension Reform Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Pension Reform Adjustment Loan
            Project will support the Government's efforts to
            finance the transition to a fully funded pension system by
            financing part of the estimated 1.7 percent of the GDP
            (Gross Domestic Product) fiscal deficit brought about by
            pension reform. The move to a funded system will continue
            the transition to a market economy by encouraging savings,
            creating an attitude of self-reliance among the population,
            reducing the public sector, and deepening capital markets.
            The loan will be disbursed in three tranches. By providing
            for the development of non-state accumulation plans, the
            pension reform will foster the development of capital
            markets and improve the aggregate economic efficiency of
            investments. The reform will also develop skills needed in a
            market economy bolstering the financial sector, the banking
            sector, and the insurance industry. The reform will reduce
            payroll taxation and, as a result, encourage employment.
            While the reform initially incurs additional budgetary
            costs, in the longer run, as benefits from the old system
            are phased out, budgetary costs will be reduced
            considerably. In the longer run, the reform will lead to
            increased savings and faster economic growth.
